clues.text: Though the city is now known as Beijing, this dog isn't called a Beijingese
A small dog with a short nose, or the character Robert Mitchum played in "War & Remembrance"
Dark-tongued doggie whose name is a synonym for "food"
In its native Tibet it's called "apso seng kye", which means "bark lion sentry dog"
It's also called "the barkless dog of Africa"
A peneplain is a once hilly or mountainous area that has almost been leveled by this process
Nickname for the circum-Pacific belt where 3/4 of all the world's earthquakes occur
This European island's largest glacier, Vatnajökull, is as big as all other glaciers in Europe combined
The 3 fuels formed of fossilized organic matter & known as "fossil fuels"
Deposits of lime shells from protozoans form the primary ingredient of this sedimentary rock
In "South Pacific", you'll hear this island "call you: come away, come away"
In "My Fair Lady", Freddy felt this high when walking "On The Street Where You Live"
In "September Song", this month, not October, follows September
Anthony Newley sang, "Why can't I fall in love like any other man and maybe then I'll know" this
The "Music Man" instrument "having his big fat say" in "76 Trombones"
One of his 1st works, it was partially set in the year 802,701
Country in which Wells set "The War of the Worlds"
J. M. Barrie, it's said, told Wells, "It is very well to be able to write books, but can you waggle" these
Completes the title of his 1933 look into the future of mankind, "The Shape of..."
Wells' letters & papers are held in the city of Urbana at the University of this central state
A gherkin is a small one of these used for pickling
If you were served "poisson et petit pois" in Paris, you'd get fish & this vegetable
Like the turnip, this root vegetable can trace its "nip" ending back to the same root, "nepe"
As asparagus is eaten in spears, bamboo is eaten in this "similar" form
The potatolike "Eleocharis tuberosa", it's found on pond bottoms & in Chinese dishes
We use this 5-letter French word to describe something outmoded or past its prime
Italian for "broad", it's a musical direction meaning to play slowly
"Ricksha" is a shortened form of this Asian word meaning "man power carriage"
The Hindi word for an elephant seat -- the one you ride on, not the one it sits on
The Swedish word for hot mulled punch
Egyptians believed Apis, a sacred bull, was son of a virgin cow impregnated when struck by this
By a twist of fate, Jocasta was both mother & this to Antigone
Described as birds with the faces of maidens, these monsters snatched people & carried them off
Pegasus, the winged horse, was born from the neck of the Medusa after this man cut off her head
She was the royal sorceress of Colchis, niece of Circe, & wife of Jason
A map with a scale of <sup>1</sup><sub>/63,360</sub> will represent one of these as 1 inch
As the lines of latitude on a map are called parallels, the lines of longitude are called these
Using pictures of landmarks to watch for, Rand McNally published its 1st guide to these in 1907
2nd century Greco-Egyptian whose "Geography" was still being used to design maps in the 15th century
The science of toponymics tries to standardize these on maps around the world

rounds.comments: (Alex: These are radio shows that have gone on to become television shows.)

clues.text: John Larkin played this attorney on radio, Raymond Burr on TV
He led the "Talent Scouts", 1st on radio, then later on TV
June Whitley played Margaret Anderson to Robert Young's Jim on this 1949 radio series
This 1960s rural sitcom was based on a 1950 radio show starring Gale Gordon & Bea Benaderet
Turning 50 in 1987, this CBS soap is the only one left in production that began on radio
In the 15th century this pair ruled Castile & Aragon, uniting 2 of Spain's main kingdoms
Under the threat of civil war, King John granted this charter on June 15, 1215
The breakup of the dual monarchy of these 2 countries in 1918 marked the end of the Hapsburg empire
Winston Churchill said this, AKA the Battle of the Ardennes, was the greatest American battle of World War II
A September 5, 1793 French decree officially started this; it lasted just under a year
Thanks to Eisenhower's urging, these 2 words were added to the Pledge of Allegiance in 1954
This country has rewritten its anthem from "in all thy sons command" to the gender-neutral "in all of us command"
You can still view a trailer online for the third "Star Wars" film when this edgier word was in the title, not "return"
As this Broadway musical was being translated to the big screen, Sondheim revealed that Rapunzel would not die
An 18th c. Philly printer put out a work called simply "Encyclopaedia", with less London bias & this title word removed
Figuratively, you can "throw down" one of these armored gloves to issue a challenge
In the 2000s pro baseball's Ichiro Suzuki won this defensive award 10 straight times
This soft, delicate leather used to make gloves comes from young goats
Insert your hands for warmth into this fur or wool cylinder open at both ends
A cesta is a long, curved wicker basket worn on the hand during the playing of this sport

rounds.text: Nazi Germany annexed this nation & divided it into regions of the Alps & the Danube; the Allies later divided it into 4 sectors
